reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s opening analogy (powered flight/selection honing in on a narrow target) used to rebut the inference from “no easy eutopia” to near-zero expected flourishing. That analogy is relevant, but it’s not structurally central to the essay’s later case, which largely rests on substantive discussion of WAM-convergence, partial convergence plus trade, and blockers/threats. So centrality is modest. Within that limited target, the critique reasonably weakens the analogy by highlighting a key disanalogy: aviation had rapid iteration and clear empirical feedback, whereas ‘moral truth’ about cosmic-scale futures plausibly lacks cheap tests and fast, unambiguous feedback, making ‘honing in’ harder. However, it doesn’t show the essay’s broader claim false, and the essay itself already emphasizes hard epistemics and divergence, so the additional damage is limited. Most claims are plausible though somewhat overstated (e.g., saying moral convergence has “none” of the relevant properties; there can be partial feedback via local moral experiments/institutions). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: The aviation analogy fails because moral progress lacks iterative feedback mechanisms
